title: How to Make a Christmas Card Jigsaw Puzzle

steps.headline: Arrange the cards on a clean, flat work surface.
Remove the front of each card from its back piece.
steps.description: Take a digital photo of the card before it is cut. Print a complete picture out as the guide for each puzzle.

steps.headline: On the back of the card (non-picture side), draw jigsaw pieces freehand using a pencil.
steps.description: Use your imagination to form shapes, or follow common patterns in a jigsaw puzzle. The amount of pieces will depend on how difficult you want the puzzle to be and how patient you are with cutting out the pieces. For an easier puzzle, 5 to 6 puzzles is great; for a harder puzzle, make up to 25 pieces.

steps.headline: Cut the cards into jigsaw shapes.
steps.description: Use a pair of small, sharp scissors suitable for cutting paper. Cut carefully to prevent tears or poor fit.

steps.headline: Place the card pieces into either a shallow box or a resealable plastic bag.
steps.description: Glue or staple the printed image to the outside of the box or resealable bag. Keep card boxes to use as little jigsaw boxes.

steps.headline: Tell each player to assemble as many cards as possible correctly.
Set a time limit of about 3 minutes.
Announce the winner.
steps.description: The winner is the player with the most correctly assembled cards.

text: Making the Jigsaw Puzzle Pieces Arrange the cards on a clean, flat work surface.  Remove the front of each card from its back piece. Take a digital photo of the card before it is cut. Print a complete picture out as the guide for each puzzle. On the back of the card (non-picture side), draw jigsaw pieces freehand using a pencil. Use your imagination to form shapes, or follow common patterns in a jigsaw puzzle. The amount of pieces will depend on how difficult you want the puzzle to be and how patient you are with cutting out the pieces. For an easier puzzle, 5 to 6 puzzles is great; for a harder puzzle, make up to 25 pieces. Cut the cards into jigsaw shapes. Use a pair of small, sharp scissors suitable for cutting paper. Cut carefully to prevent tears or poor fit. Place the card pieces into either a shallow box or a resealable plastic bag. Glue or staple the printed image to the outside of the box or resealable bag. Keep card boxes to use as little jigsaw boxes. Making a Jigsaw Assemble players for the game.  Tell each player to assemble as many cards as possible correctly.  Set a time limit of about 3 minutes.  Announce the winner. The winner is the player with the most correctly assembled cards.
